Award.AwardTitle: Life STEM EAGER: Exploring the efficacy of an undergraduate voluntary intervention using near-peer mentoring to transfer positive behaviors through extracurricular team competition

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The ECR program emphasizes fundamental STEM education research that will generate foundational knowledge in the field. This project will explore an early-stage, untested intervention aimed at promoting ways to help underrepresented minority students succeed in introductory biology courses and persist in STEM careers. The project will study whether combining team-based geocaching gameplay with near-peer mentoring will help students master content and skills in biology. It will also examine whether or not the intervention will transform students' beliefs and behaviors about science as they take part in problem-based learning activities and content-driven social interactions. The intervention will take place in an out-of-class context to help students develop self-worth and self-direction as part of building a broader STEM community of learners. Near-peer mentors of similar backgrounds as the students will be trained in both academic and social areas to ensure that students gain a deeper understanding of biology and see the relevance of this field to their lives and other STEM disciplines.

The study will take a radically different approach to research by combining theories to examine multiple factors shown to synergistically influence motivation and improve learning for underrepresented students. Through a mixed methods approach, data will be collected and analyzed on both academic and personal factors. Despite these notable aspects of the project, this intervention will have risks. Specifically, it is a novel research topic, and the activities do not include direct day-to-day faculty supervision or regular graded classwork. Additionally, the project will require students to be self-motivated and self-directed to complete the tasks, and will neither guarantee that students will volunteer to participate nor resist social pressures that may prevent them from engaging in the study. Therefore, it is not clear if this study can be done or if it will alter students' academic knowledge and skills or beliefs and behaviors. However, the intervention is potentially transformative in shaping the development of effective models of intervention and reducing the number of underrepresented students who switch to different majors or drop out of STEM fields. These potential outcomes make this project a priority for funding and will contribute to foundational knowledge about STEM education in the ECR program portfolio.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the last 3 years, Project Knowledge (PK) has transitioned from the campus of Virginia State University to Petersburg High School. The new partnership with Petersburg City Public Schools and Community In Schools has allowed this "non-academic" academic intervention to begin fostering successful academic habits with high school students.  Prior to the move, PK had proven successful at increasing the rate of retention for entering freshmen students who had a desire to major in a STEM discipline. Once assigned to a small group consisting of one upper-class student in the same STEM major to 5 entering first year students, individuals within the group established relational bonds. It was from these relationships that strong academic habits, beliefs and behaviors became established, reinforced and entrenched. Since the PK intervention focused on the antecedent behaviors and skills, that are needed to make good grades, such as time management, organized note taking, and active studying, to name a few, we believed that these skills could (and should) be taught to students before they entered college. 

In the spring of 2020, COVID caused the rapid disruption of in-person schooling  and forced the shift to virtual instruction. Despite the massive challenges, PK continued to operate but not at the capacity seen the previous year when meeting in person at Petersburg High School. Surprisingly, the shift to virtual learning provided a platform for deeper and more meaningful interactions between the VSU mentors and those PHS students who remained engaged. The VSU mentors rose to the occasion in displaying a higher level of creativity, discipline and commitment that was demanded by these challenging circumstances. Results show that even when forced to switch to virtual training during COVID, PK still served as a protective factor against the loneliness and isolation that many students felt when they were no longer attending school in person.

According to our theoretical framework, protective factors are essential in bolstering a student's ability to continually engage in academics, while risk factors decrease the likelihood of continued academic engagement.  Our goal, put simply, is to increase protective factors and decrease risk factors.  We do this by training VSU college mentors to interact with high school students using a variety of tools. Geocache was to have been one way, but we found that math games and science lab activities were also effective in garnering interest in our program. However, it is clear that these activities were necessary but insufficient in keeping students engaged over time. For that, we required relationship building between the mentors and their mentees.

The PK college mentors deliver the intervention only after intensive training. During the spring of 2021, mentors delivered training modules that included "Coping with Anxiety and Depression," "Expressing Gratitude" and "Meditation."  These topics were hypothesized to aid students in self-regulation. According to our conceptual framework and supported by psychological studies, self-regulation and emotion regulation are characteristics of high performing students.

During the eight years that PK existed on VSU's campus as an intervention and summer bridge program, over 200 students participated. Every PK mentor was recruited from the pool of mentees. We are committed to using this same model at Petersburg High school. Our goal is to identify and recruit rising juniors and seniors from among our participants and then train them to mentor incoming PHS freshmen students. We wish to make the training their summer job.

In preparation for the next iteration of PK at PHS, we will continue to utilize a combination of online resources and in-person meetings. We will add regular visits to the VSU campus in addition to our web presence and social media. The relationship between Virginia State University and Petersburg High School is critically important: it is within our mission at VSU to recruit our future student body from our own neighborhood. We would like to disseminate this model to all of the nation's Historically Black Colleges and Minority Serving institutions.
